questions.text: An elderly male with heart disease has sudden painless loss of vision with a systolic murmur over the chest. Ocular examination reveals a cherry red spot in the macula, clear AC, with the perception of light positive and pupillary reflex negative. The most probable diagnosis is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

CRAO Central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO) It occurs due to obstruction at the level of lamina cribrosa . Symptoms. Patients complain of sudden painless loss of vision . The patient may give a history of transient visual loss (amaurosis fugax) in the past. Signs Visual acuity is markedly reduced (< 3/60 in 90% of cases) Direct pupillary reflex is absent and relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD) is positive. Fundus examination shows Marked narrowing of retinal arteries and mild narrowing of retinal veins. The retina becomes milky white due to ischaemic edema. A cherry-red spot is seen in the center of the macula due to vascular choroid shining through the thin retina in the foveal region, in contrast to the surrounding pale retina Cattle tracking, i.e., segmentation of the blood column is seen in the retinal veins.

Highyeild:

Atrophic changes. In most cases retinal edema resolves over 4–6 weeks and atrophic changes in the form of grossly attenuated thread-like arteries atrophic appearing retina and consecutive optic atrophy occur in long-standing cases

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: Option: B. CRVO - Central Retinal Vein Occlusion Ischaemic CRVO Ischaemic CRVO (hemorrhagic retinopathy) refers to acute (sudden) complete occlusion of the central retinal vein. It is characterized by marked sudden visual loss and RAPD. Central retinal vein occlusion (nonischemic) Early cases on fundus examination reveal: Massive engorgement, congestion, and tortuosity of retinal veins, Massive retinal hemorrhages (giving a ‘splashed tomato’ appearance), Numerous cotton wool spots (usually more than 6 to 10), The disc shows edema and hyperemia, The macular area is full of hemorrhages and is severely oedematous and Breakthrough vitreous hemorrhage may be seen in some cases. Option: D. Amaurosis fugax Amaurosis fugax is a temporary loss of vision in one or both eyes due to a lack of blood flow to the retina. The retina is the light-sensitive layer of tissue at the back of the eyeball. Option: C. Macular choroiditis with bacterial endocarditis Litten spots are cited as the least common physical finding in infective endocarditis, occurring in 2% of patients. Further ophthalmic signs of infective endocarditis include conjunctival hemorrhages, chorioretinitis, and endophthalmitis; the latter two being more commonly seen in fungal endocarditis.

Extraedge:

Fundus fluorescein angiography (FFA) shows a delay in arterial filing (cilioretinal artery when present will fill in the early phase) and masking of choroidal vasculature due to retinal edema.

questions.text: 100-day glaucoma is seen in which of the following:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

CRVO Central Retinal Vein Occlusion Ischaemic CRVO Ischaemic CRVO (hemorrhagic retinopathy) refers to acute (sudden) complete occlusion of the central retinal vein. It is characterized by marked sudden visual loss and RAPD . Central retinal vein occlusion (nonischemic) Early cases on fundus examination reveal: Massive engorgement, congestion, and tortuosity of retinal veins, Massive retinal hemorrhages (giving a ‘splashed tomato’ appearance), Numerous cotton wool spots (usually more than 6 to 10), The disc shows edema and hyperemia, The macular area is full of hemorrhages and is severely oedematous and Breakthrough vitreous hemorrhage may be seen in some cases.

Highyeild:

Pathognomonic features for ischaemic CRVO differentiating it from non-ischaemic CRVO are: Presence of relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD), Visual field defects, and Reduced amplitude of b-wave of electroretinogram.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Steroid-induced glaucoma Steroid-induced glaucoma is considered to be a type of secondary open-angle glaucoma , caused by increased resistance to the outflow of aqueous at the level of the trabecular meshwork. In this condition, there is increased production and decreased destruction of the extracellular matrix of the trabecular meshwork. Option: B. CRAO Emboli dislodged from the carotid artery are the most common cause of CRAO, from either an unstable atherosclerotic plaque or a cardiac source. Embolism, as follows: Cholesterol is the most common typ e, but it can also be from calcium, bacteria, or talc from intravenous drug use. Option: D. Neovascular glaucoma Neovascular glaucoma (NVG) is a severe form of secondary glaucoma characterized by the proliferation of fibrovascular tissue in the anterior chamber angle.

Extraedge:

Complications. Rubeosis iridis neovascular glaucoma (NVG) can occur within 3 months of onset (so also called 90 days glaucoma ), vitreous hemorrhage, and proliferative retinopathy.

questions.text: This is the fundus Image of a 50-year-old patient with a history of hypertension and diabetes. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Branch retinal vein occlusion Branch retinal vein occlusion (BRVO) is more common than central retinal vein occlusion. It may occur as: Hemispheric occlusion due to occlusion in the main branch at the disc. Quadrantic occlusion due to occlusion at the level of AV crossing, and Small branch occlusion either as macular branch occlusion or peripheral branch occlusion. Features of BRVO are as below: Retinal edema and hemorrhages are limited to the area drained by the affected vein. Vision is affected only when the macular area is involved.

Highyeild:

Retinal edema and hemorrhages are limited to the area drained by the affected vein. Vision is affected only when the macular area is involved. Secondary glaucoma occurs rarely in these cases.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Central retinal vein occlusion Central retinal vein occlusion is an occlusion of the main retinal vein posterior to the lamina cribrosa of the optic nerve and is typically caused by thrombosis. Central retinal vein occlusion is further divided into two categories: nonischemic (perfused) and ischemic (nonperfused). Option: B. Diabetic retinopathy Diabetes complication that affects the It's caused by damage to the blood vessels of the light-sensitive tissue at the back of the eye (retina). At first, diabetic retinopathy might cause no symptoms or only mild vision problems. Option: C. Hypertensive retinopathy Hypertension also leads to more advanced diabetic retinopathy progression . Hypertensive optic neuropathy can cause chronic papilledema, leading to optic nerve atrophy and severe loss of visual acuity. It may also be a risk factor for glaucoma. Recently the term 'proliferative hypertensive retinopathy' has been coined

Extraedge:

Chronic macular edema and neovascularization may occur as complications of BRVO in about one-third of cases.

questions.text: A 50 yrs. the old male presents in an emergency with a sudden loss of vision. He also gave a history of fever, weight loss, and headache which is more intense along the course of superficial temporal arteries. Fundus examination shows The treatment modality for this patient is-
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Anti- TNF The patient complains of a headache that is more intense along the course of the superficial temporal artery . The fundus picture shows a pale retina with sparing of the territory supplied by the cilioretinal artery [ Central retinal artery occlusion]. The probable diagnosis is Giant cell arteritis. Giant cell arteritis: It is a chronic inflammatory disorder of large to medium-sized arteries that principally affects arteritis in the head-temporal artery and ophthalmic artery.

Highyeild:

It is a T- cell-mediated immune response that increases the proinflammatory factor TNF. So, the mainstay of treatment is Corticosteroid and Anti-TNF.

Extraedge:

Side Effects are more common with higher doses of corticosteroid treatment and can cause bone loss, muscle weakness, cataracts, and skin bruising.

questions.text: A person presents with painful unilateral dimness of vision. He gives a history of the persistence of After Images. What is the likely diagnosis -
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Retrobulbar Neuritis Retrobulbar neuritis - optic nerve affected behind the eyeball The optic disc appears normal The condition may be truly described as the patient seeing nothing and the doctor seeing nothing Most frequent type in adults Associated with multiple sclerosis Papillitis - optic nerve head is affected Hyperemia and edema of the optic disc May he be associated with peripapillary flame-shaped hemorrhage Retinal veins are torturous Exudates may accumulate upon disc Most common type in children Neuroretinitis - concomitant swelling of optic nerve head and macula Macular star educates that form around the macula give the appearance of the star Least common type Not associated with multiple sclerosis Due to viral infection

Highyeild:

Clinical features- U/L profound sudden LOV Associated with painful ocular movements Defective color vision especially red and green Defect in-depth perception called the Pulfrichs phenomenon Uthoff's phenomenon - aggravation of symptoms due to heat or exertion

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. Papilloedema Papilledema is a term that is exclusively used when disc swelling is secondary to increased intracranial pressure (ICP). It must be distinguished from optic disc swelling from other causes which are simply termed "optic disc edema" Option: C. Ocular ischemic syndrome Ocular ischemic syndrome (OIS) is a rare, but vision-threatening condition associated with severe carotid artery occlusive disease (stenosis or occlusion) leading to ocular hypoperfusion. Principal symptoms include visual loss, transient visual loss, and ischemic ocular pain. Option: D. CRVO Central retinal vein occlusion is an occlusion of the main retinal vein posterior to the lamina cribrosa of the optic nerve and is typically caused by thrombosis . Central retinal vein occlusion is further divided into two categories: nonischemic (perfused) and ischemic (nonperfused).

Extraedge:

Signs Earliest is RAPD Tenderness at the insertion of SR, MR Central and centrocecal scotoma Optic disc edema

questions.text: A 48-year-old lady presents with unilateral mild axial proptosis. There is no history of redness or pain. Which of the following is the most appropriate investigation?

options.label: A
options.text: CT scan to rule out meningioma

options.label: B
options.text: USG to rule out orbital pseudotumor

options.label: C
options.text: T3 and T4 measurement to rule out thyrotoxicosis

questions.correct_answer: C. T3 and T4 measurement to rule out thyrotoxicosis
questions.explanation:
Solution:

T3 and T4 measurement to rule out thyrotoxicosis Grave s disease is the most common cause of unilateral and bilateral proptosis in adults It may occur in patients who are hyperthyroid, euthyroid, or hypothyroid Pathogenesis- it is an autoimmune ( type II) disorder in which antibodies produce the following changes Inflammation and enlargement of the extraocular muscles followed by fibrosis leading to compressive and restrictive myopathy Infiltration of inflammatory cells in orbital fat Clinical features- Soft tissue signs - periorbital and lid edema with conjunctival injection ( goldzeihers sign earliest sign), chemosis, and superior limbic keratoconjunctivitis The earliest symptoms are excessive lacrimation, grittiness, and photophobia

Highyeild:

Eyelid signs - with lid lag on infraduction (Von Graefe's sign) , eye globe lag on supraduction (Kocher's sign) , a widened palpebral fissure during fixation (Dalrymple's sign) an incapacity of closing the eyelids completely (lagophthalmos, Stellwag's sign) Abadie's sign Elevator muscle of the upper eyelid is spastic. Ballet's sign paralysis of one or more EOM Cowen's sign Extensive hippus of consensual pupillary reflex Enroth's sign Edema of the upper eyelid Gifford's sign Difficulty in eversion of the upper lid. Griffith's sign Lower lid lag on upward gaze Hertoghe's sign Loss of eyebrows laterally Jellinek's sign Superior eyelid folds are hyperpigmented Joffroy's sign Absent creases in the forehead on upward gaze. Mann's sign Eyes seem to be situated at different levels because of their tanned skin. Möbius's sign Lack of convergence Proptosis - exophthalmos - axial, non pulsatile- 2nd most common sign leads to exposure to keratitis Restrictive myopathy - ocular motility is restricted initially by edema and later by fibrosis leading to diplopia, squint, and loss of bell s phenomenon The sequence of involvement is IR, MR, SR, LR (IMSR) The earliest restriction is usually of elevation due to contracture of IR followed by abduction restriction Compressive optic neuropathy leads to visual loss

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. CT scan to rule out meningioma - CT scan is not the most appropriate Option: B. USG to rule out orbital pseudotumor - no, using is not used in this case. Option: D. Doppler to rule out hemangioma. - Doppler is not the most appropriate

Extraedge:

Rx- Lubricating drops Botox to Muller's muscle Systemic steroids Orbital decompression

questions.text: Below Figure: A 10-year-old girl is referred for an ophthalmologic examination after failing her school eye examination. Her best-corrected visual acuity is 20/50 in her right eye and 20/40 in her left. Examination reveals a normal anterior segment with an abnormal fundus appearance bilaterally. Her left eye is shown. Which one of the following would be most useful in establishing the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Fluorescein angiogram This is a patient with Stargardt disease , which is thought to be a result of lipofuscin Accumulation within the retinal pigment epithelium; this in turn results in a characteristic "silent choroid" effect on Fluorescein angiogram in which the lipofuscin blocks underlying choroidal fluorescence. The macula may exhibit a mottled hyperfluorescent appearance . The majority of patients have normal results on Electrophysiologic tests, although ERG Amplitudes are frequently in the low normal range.

Highyeild:

When the peripheral retina is predominantly involved with the macula affected to a lesser degree, the term fundus Flavimaculatus is used.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Electrooculogram (EOG) The electrooculogram (EOG) measures the cornea-positive standing potential relative to the back of the eye. By attaching skin electrodes outside the eye near the lateral and medial canthus, the potential can be measured by having the patient move the eyes horizontally a set distance. Option: B. ERG The electroretinogram (ERG) is a diagnostic test that measures the electrical activity of the retina in response to a light stimulus. The ERG arises from currents generated directly by retinal neurons in combination with contributions from retinal glia. Option: C. Visually evoked cortical potential The term visually evoked potential (VEP) refers to electrical potentials recorded from the scalp overlying visual cortex that has been extracted from the electroencephalogram by signal averaging. Usually, the recording electrode is placed on the midline of the occipital scalp at the back of the head.

questions.text: A 76-year-old man is scheduled for cataract Surgery in his right eye as his visual acuity has decreased to 20/200 due to cataracts. He previously underwent cataract surgery in the Opposite eye, which resulted in an expulsive Choroidal hemorrhage and no light perception vision. All of the following may be steps to prevent an expulsive hemorrhage in this eye:

options.label: A
options.text: Placement of patient in Trendelenburg position

options.label: B
options.text: Use of a Honan balloon after peribulbar anesthesia

options.label: C
options.text: Closure of the wound with nylon sutures

options.label: D
options.text: Careful control of blood pressure during surgery

questions.correct_answer: A. Placement of patient in Trendelenburg position
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Placement of patient in Trendelenburg position Risk factors for expulsive choroidal Hemorrhage include myopia, glaucoma, Atherosclerotic vascular disease, hypertension, and previous expulsive hemorrhage in the opposite eye. Using as small an incision as possible along with being ready to perform a sclerotomy is important. Rapid wound closure is required once this complication is recognized to prevent iris prolapse and expulsion of the lens, vitreous, and blood . Sclerotomies may also be performed using a blade or trephine to drain blood posterior to the ora serrata.

Highyeild:

It occurs in approximately 1% of cases and causes a forward shift of the iris-lens diaphragm , with prolapse of posterior structures and a change in the red reflex.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B . Decompression before opening the globe with digital pressure or another device such as a Honan balloon may be helpful. Option: C .The wound should be closed with nonabsorbable, preferably nylon sutures to prevent delayed hemorrhage . It is also beneficial to keep blood pressure controlled and the level of anesthesia deep (if general anesthesia is used) during surgery. Option: D . Shelved or self-sealing incisions allow more rapid closure and depressurization of the globe should bleeding occur. Placing the patient in the Trendelenburg position would increase Pressure around the eye, thus increasing the chance of having an expulsive hemorrhage.

Extraedge:

Choroidal hemorrhage is the most sight-threatening complication of cataract surgery, its incidence is fortunately low
